bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Herbert Putnam, January 7, 1930

div1.p: Carter expresses her appreciation of the Library of Congress and states that her work is nearly done.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Herbert Putnam, January 7, 1930
div1.opener:
Book, Miscl
Library of Congress
Dr. Putnam
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
January 7, 1930.
Dear Doctor Putnam:
div1.p:
Allow me to express my deep appreciation of the
renewal of the cards giving me permission to “(a) draw
books from the Library and (b) have access to the stacks
on subjects connected with the completion of the work on
my Father's book on yellow fever. I should have earlier
acknowledged your kindness, but have been over in Baltimore,
working with Dr. Wade Hampton Frost, who is doing the final
editing of the MS.

I am sure that you will be glad to hear the end
really does seem in sight, although not yet of so “high a
visibility” as to make “accurate chronological predictions'.”

I can never adequately express all that I owe both
to yourself and to your staff for the perfect facilities
for my work, which have been afforded me, and for the inter-
est kindness and courtesy with which any assistance that I
required has been extended.

With all manner of good wishes for the New Year,
I remain
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, Laura Armistead Carter Dr. Herbert Putnam,
Librarian,
Library of Congress,
Washington,
D. C.
